Problem 6. Fix an integer d. What is the largest sum-free subset of [N]d?
Comments. This problem was raised in an unpublished note of Peter Cameron
from 2002 [53], as well as (in the case d = 2) in [54, Problem 424], where it is attrib-
uted to Harut Aydinian. Writing fd(N) for the quantity in question, the most inter-
esting part of the question seems to be determining cd := lim supN→∞N −dfd(N).
It is very well-known and easy that c1 = 1
2. Elsholtz and Rackham [96] showed
that c2 = 3
5, and gave lower bounds for larger d. In general, it seems to be believed
that a ‘slice’ {(x1, . . . , xd) : u ⩽x1 + · · · + xd < 2u} is optimal, where u is chosen
to maximise the number of points in this set.
